 FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA TRANSIT FACILITATION PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY Borrower: Republican Road Organization of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Guarantor: Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia Executing Agencies: Republican Road Organization of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (RO); Ministry of Transport and Communications (MTC); Ministry of Urban Development, Civil Engineering, and Environment (MUDCEE); and Customs Agency. Beneficiaries: Project benefits would accrue to the economy as a whole. The reduction of transport costs expected from the project would increase the competitiveness of the country's goods. In the short run, the project would help to alleviate the impact on transport costs of the disruption of traffic in the Balkans. Loan Amount: US$24.0 million equivalent. Terms: Twenty years, including five years of grace, at the standard variable interest rate. Project Objectives: The main objectives of the project are to assist the Government to: (i) address the crisis created for transport in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia caused by the closure of the Serbian and Greek borders, through the facilitation of East-West transport so as to reduce transport costs; and (ii) strengthen the road management capabilities of MTC, MUDCEE and RO, particularly in the area of planning and pavement management. Project Description: The project would have three components: (i) the civil works component would improve the country's access to the ports of Bulgaria and Albania through the rehabilitation and upgrading of about 60 km of the East-West Corridor; (ii) the transit facilitation component will fund technical assistance and equipment for the development and implementation of a
 ii modem customs system and the improvement of transit times; and (iii) the institutional strengthening component will fund technical assistance and training to strengthen MTC, MUDCEE and RO in the area of economic evaluation of different road interventions and life-cost planning for pavement management. Project Benefits: The proposed project will facilitate the international movement of goods and passengers through the reduction of transport costs in one of the main export-import corridors in the country. This will be accomplished by reducing congestion in the Tetovo-Gostivar road section, decreasing the present value of road expenditures in the Kichevo-Botun road section by rehabilitating the road now and avoiding more expensive reconstruction at a later date, and reducing border crossing waiting time by incorporating modem customs procedures. The technical assistance component is also expected to improve the allocation of the scarce national resources. Project Risks: The project does not present any technical or environmental risks. The main risk is related to the fragile political and economic situation facing the country, which may impact the availability of counterpart funds. That risk, however, is within acceptable levels because of the high priority of the road works, the historic financial independence and solvency of RO, the small share that the proposed investments represent in RO's budget, and the amount of retroactive financing proposed for the project. There are also risks related to the possible lack of coordination among the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania and Bulgaria, to improve border crossings, thus reducing the expected benefits. This is mitigated by ongoing agreements, that are being implemented satisfactorily. In addition, the current presence of the Bank in the transport sector of the three countries, provides an opportunity for encouraging systematic tri-lateral performance monitoring at the borders, which would further reduce that risk. Economic Rate of Return: About 20% for the civil works component.

 FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA TRANSIT FACILITATION PROJECT I. THE ECONOMY AND THE TRANSPORT SECTOR A. Background 1.1 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is a small, landlocked economy with a population of 2.2 million people. Population growth is just under 1 % per year, and per capita income in 1993 was US$780, down from US$1,360 in 1990. Past policies emphasizing industry have made this a dominant sector constituting 47% of GDP; services constitute about 38%, and agriculture 15%. The economy of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is also very open (annual exports and imports equal nearly 65% of GDP) and hence extremely vulnerable to any impediments to its external trade. 1.2 From its inception three years ago following the breakup of Yugoslavia, in common with other countries undergoing transition to market economies, the country has had to face large-scale dislocation in production, employment and social welfare. Also, economic management in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been vastly complicated by the United Nations (UN) trade and transit sanctions against former Yugoslavia (Serbia/Montenegro), and by the closure of its southern border by Greece which deprive it of its access to Salonika, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's closest and most economic outlet to the sea. The country had therefore to rely on alternative routes which substantially increased transport costs. Together all these factors have brought wrenching changes in the economy, involving persistent drops in output (13% each year in 1990-93) and rising rate of unemployment (from 23% in 1990 to 29% in 1993) at the same time as various subsidies were cut and prices soared (annual inflation averaged 407% during 1990-93). 1.3 The Government's ongoing stabilization program combines an incomes policy, tight monetary stance, a flexible exchange rate regime, and domestic resource mobilization, the latter involving reduction of distortionary expenditures--e.g., agricultural input subsidies--as well as efficient revenue enhancement measures. These efforts pulled the country back from the brink of hyperinflation in 1993 and, in 1994, have lowered inflation and enabled the authorities to stay well within targeted performance agreed with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Structural policy reforms already in place include liberalization of trade and pricing policies; a major tax reform involving rationalization of income and sales tax; passage of two laws to advance privatization and establishment of a proactive task force to restructure important public enterprises.
 2 1.4 Despite commendable initiatives to date under very difficult conditions, the country still faces a long, hard agenda of industrial, financial and social sector reforms necessary to establish a coherent policy and institutional framework for sustained growth and poverty reduction. The country has been engaged in a policy dialogue with the Bank and the IMF and appears prepared to deepen economic reforms over the medium term. Its medium-term growth prospects will critically depend also on availability of sufficient external finance. B. The Transport Sector 1.5 The main transport infrastructure in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia consists of 8,216 km of roads (of which about 4,900 are paved), a railway network of 700km, and two international airports in Skopje and Ohrid. The primary road network, under the jurisdiction of the RO, is 3,526 km long and carries about 75% of the country's freight traffic. Until Greece closed its borders, the railways concentrated on the transport of low-value bulk commodities to and from the port of Salonika in Greece. The configuration of the transport system was influenced by geopolitical considerations of the former Yugoslavia, which emphasized the development of the North-South Corridor (namely the Trans-Yugoslav Highway) which was developed with Bank financing (para. 1.15). 1.6 The development of the East-West corridor, although growing in importance for domestic traffic and as a feeder of the North-South artery, was hampered by the political and economic isolation of Albania, which until 1992 prohibited transit through its territory, and to some extent, by the administrative difficulties of crossing Bulgaria and the commercial relations and practices inherent to the centrally planned economies. The situation has now changed: the North-South corridor is closed due to the UN-imposed blockade of Serbia/Montenegro and unresolved issues with Greece. As a result, the port of Salonika no longer serves the landlocked former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. Road transport through the East-West road corridor has now become the lifeline of the country's economy. Although the Government is planning to complete the East-West rail link to Bulgaria (para. 1.8), the road corridor is now the only connection of the country with the rest of the world. The road subsector is discussed in detail in Chapter II. 1.7 Macedonian Railways consists today of a 700km network employing a staff of about 5,300 for basic services, down from more than 6,600 employees in 1989. Staff reductions are largely the result of attrition and an early retirement scheme. The railway company is also in the process of privatizing other non-core enterprises (employing 2,500 to 3,000 persons) for forwarding services, trucking, tourism, etc. Freight movements in 1990 were about 6.5 million tons a year, but the volume in 1993 was down to 3.4 million (all local traffic), as services to the port of Salonika were interrupted. Even in the past, the railways made significant operating losses, partly because rail tariffs were set at levels well below costs. Although operating losses are now not substantial, the balance has been achieved by an unsustainable reduction of maintenance. Also, because of uncollected receivables, the railways have a cash flow deficit of about US$1 million per month, financed
 3 through short-term borrowing. Access to loans, however, will be curtailed in 1995, and the railways are looking at ways to address this issue through increased tariffs. In the medium- term, the economic role of the railways should be assessed and unprofitable lines and/or services should be discontinued. The Government, as part of its economic restructuring program, is planning to privatize ancillary services and to clearly separate commercial activities from those social services requiring direct subsidies. 1.8 The railway company is also considering to construct a 60 km rail link to Bulgaria as part of the government's plan to diversify land transport links with neighboring countries. The cost of this link has been estimated at some US$1 10 million. The German Agency for Technical Cooperation (GTZ) is financing a feasibility study of this project which is to be completed by mid-1995. Transport Sector Issues 1.9 One of the main problems of the sector is to evaluate the future volume and pattern of traffic demand. The shift to a market economy is likely to result in less emphasis on transport intensive industries, such as minerals, and more on higher value added light industry, such as textiles and agro-industry. The latter will require lower transport volumes and are more likely to use road transport than rail transport. The comparative advantage of the country in the production of perishable goods, will also result in increased demand for air transport, an area in which the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) is providing support. ' 1.10 Within this uncertain environment, the transport sector agenda is being dominated by two main issues, the crisis generated by the blockades in Serbia/Montenegro and Greece and the resulting emergency movement of trade through Albania and Bulgaria (the East-West corridor), and the future role of the railways in the country's economy. The first government priority is to address the current crisis and upgrade the East-West road link, an objective that will be supported under the proposed project. Also the Government is considering completion of the railway link with Bulgaria (para. 1.8) and construction of an oil pipeline from the port of Burgas. In addition, as part of the preparation of the proposed Bank-financed Financial and Enterprise Sector Adjustment Credit (FESAC), which will focus on the restructuring of the 25 highest money-losing enterprises in the country, consultants have been retained to prepare a short-term cost reduction program and a medium-term business plan to turn the railways into a commercially-oriented enterprise. 1 .11 Border crossing remains a major bottleneck in East-West traffic due to lack of physical facilities and cumbersome procedures. Efforts to improve regional trade are taking place in an active framework of consultation and coordination under the auspices of the G-24 Group and the European Union (EU).  4 Macedonia, in particular, is taking important steps to reduce the cost imposed by long waiting times and resulting idleness of vehicles and goods. Physical facilities are being improved with bilateral financing. They include increased parking spaces, special lanes for empty vehicles and adequate inspection facilities. A study carried out by the US Customs Agency as part of bilateral US technical assistance to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, identified a program of investments and technical assistance to modernize and improve customs procedures, which served as the basis for the transit facilitation component to be financed under the project (para 3.7). 1.12 Being a landlocked country, international trade for the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia involves significant use of neighboring ports. Therefore, interface with Bulgarian and Albanian ports and concerted efforts at the borders to facilitate traffic to and from the ports should be major elements in the country's transport strategy. The Governments of Albania, Bulgaria and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are taking significant steps to improve trade flows, as reflected in several bi-lateral and multi- lateral agreements and protocols related to border crossings and to the use by the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia of the port facilities in Durres and Burgas. Also, the ongoing Transport Project in Albania, Credit 2499-ALB, includes the preparation of a master plan for the port of Durres which will address the issue of port facilities to serve the needs of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. However, much remains to be done in terms of establishing a systematic dialogue on common trade problems, identifying and implementing remedial actions and monitoring performance. The proposed project, coupled with the ongoing Bank presence in the transport sectors of Albania and Bulgaria, will provide an opportunity for encouraging and enhancing tri-lateral cooperation in transit facilitation. C. Bank Assistance Strategy 1.13 The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia became a member of the Bank, IDA and IFC on December 30, 1993 (effective February 25, 1994) upon fulfillment of the requirements of succession approved by the Executive Directors, including an agreement on a plan to clear the country's arrears to the Bank. Arrears clearance took place in February 1994, after which an Economic Recovery Loan/Credit (ERL I) was approved. The Bank's assistance strategy is focused on the following four main areas: (i) inducing a rapid development of the country's private sector through a series of adjustment operations targeted mainly at the enterprise, banking and the social sectors; (ii) developing the country's human resources in a sustainable way; (iii) maintaining the country's infrastructure, and (iv) protecting the country's natural resources and environment. The strategy emphasizes short- term economic objectives, in particular meeting the balance of payment shortages, deepening the economic restructuring, and strengthening the social safety net. This objective will be supported by the proposed FESAC and the proposed Social Reform and Technical Assistance Project, which are in an advanced stage of preparation, and by the retroactive financing proposed herein (para. 3.16). In addition, the Bank is chairing a Consultative Group designed to mobilize additional financial resources, which are critical to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's ability to overcome its depressed situation. With respect to the country's infrastructure, the Bank strategy is based on the premise that developing the transport sector capacity through restoring and diversifying trading routes will have a
 5 revitalizing impact in the country's economy. Its immediate objective would be to upgrade the East-West transport links and to improve access to naval ports in order to address the present emergency due to the interruption of North-South traffic, in a manner consistent with national priorities should trade and transport in the region once again be normalized (para. 4.4). The proposed project has been designed to implement this strategy. D. Past Bank Experience 1.14 The Bank has made 25 loans for transport to the former Republic of Yugoslavia totalling US$ 1.7 billion equivalent since 1963. These include thirteen loans to the highway subsector (Annex 1), eight loans for the railway subsector, one loan for the port of Bar, a multimodal loan for earthquake rehabilitation, and two pipeline projects. 1.15 The main emphasis in early highway lending had been on improvement of key links in the primary road network, mainly the completion of the Trans-Yugoslav Highway. Successive Project Completion Reports indicate that the projects were successful in achieving their objectives, albeit with delays due to shortages of local funds. Subsequent lending followed a sector approach and included a deeper involvement in the important areas of road maintenance, road pricing and systematic use of cost-benefit analysis in road planning. Annex 1 provides details of those projects which directly benefitted the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. II. THE HIGHWAY SUBSECTOR A. Network and Traffic 2.1 Historic trade routes, the waves of invading armies and the very rugged terrain have all played a part in the location and development of roads in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The present main highway alignments follow the old trade routes and mountain passes to provide land connections between Europe and the East. The Romans were first to build engineered roads and, although rebuilt under the Ottoman Empire and improved under Napoleon, the alignments of these major roads have changed little and still provide the most important land transportation links between the Adriatic and Black Seas and Europe and the East. 2.2 Road Network. The road network totals 8,216 km of which some 4,900 km, or about 60%, have been modernized and about 3,300 still have earth surfacing. Roads are classified as Arterial, Regional and Local. Of the total network, 915 km are Arterial, 2611 km are Regional and 4,690 km are Local. In addition to the national classification, about 520 km of the arterial roads are part of the European road network ('E' Roads). Road transport in and through the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia has been seriously disrupted since the political changes and problems in the Balkan peninsula. The UN blockade on the countries to the north and the embargo imposed by Greece have reduced international traffic on the network very substantially and have changed its pattern and direction. By 1990, the annual average daily traffic (AADT) on the Arterial Road No. 1 in the north-south direction had reached 7,000 to 10,000, with about 15,000 vehicles per day during the tourist months of July and August. Since the events in Serbia and Greece, this traffic has been reduced by 50%. However, traffic has increased on the arterial road running in the east-west direction connecting Sofia, Skopje and the port of Durres on the Adriatic Sea in Albania. As already mentioned, the road is now the country's only effective international link. The traffic on this road, which ranged from 1,500 to 5,500

Road Transport 2.6 There are three types of trucking in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia: public social sector trucking (self-managed) enterprises,2 own-account trucking (mostly in social sector industrial and manufacturing firms), and private sector operators. Social sector firms specialize in long distance and international traffic. Own-account and private operators, until recently, specialized in local transport. The road freight industry was heavily regulated until about 1989, through various laws which limited the participation of 2/ Social sector enterprises are firms owned and managed by employees and workers. In past practice, they enjoyed substantial Government financial privileges and the Government influenced their level of employment.
 8 the private sector (barriers to entry; prohibitions against international transport; more favorable tax rates and customs duties for social sector firms, etc.). These formal regulations were reinforced by various social contracts and informal arrangements which served to divide the market, and by accounting and managerial practices which permitted social sector firms to operate inefficiently and sustain losses over the long term. In addition, domestic truck manufacturing was protected in the former Yugoslavia, resulting in the use of lower quality domestic trucks by many operators. However, the regulations were unevenly enforced, which coupled with a relatively dynamic private sector, resulted in the private sector increasing their share of the market (measured in km). The regulatory framework also resulted in the inefficient growth of own account fleets: domestic producers were able to take advantage of the country's cost-plus pricing system and buy their own trucks, which they did not use efficiently, and passed on higher transport costs without penalty under conditions of excess demand. 2.7 In 1989, the Government of the former Yugoslavia passed a privatization law affecting several sectors of the economy including transport. The Government in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia continued with these reforms which are currently in place. They include: permitting the private sector to operate internationally and foreign trucks to operate inside the country, reducing tariffs and removing regulations on importing foreign vehicles; equalizing tax rates and enforcement between social sector enterprises and private sector operators; and separating the accounts of trucking and bus subsidiaries which were owned by the railways so that they would not benefit from the subsidies received by the latter. 2.8 The Government is actively working on other issues which would enhance the efficiency of the trucking industry: complete the privatization of social sector firms; train road operators in modern management practices; improve credit facilities for vehicle purchases; increase vehicle leasing arrangements; introduce a computer-based freight information system; and publicize the merits of a market-based road transport industry among decision makers. Highway Administration and Organization 2.10 Highway administration in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is unique. Until the beginning of 1990, the organization followed a pattern laid down by the Associated Labour Act of 1976 common to all the former Yugoslav Republics, by which a Community of Interest was responsible for roads policy and its administration, with work activities being carried out by independent Basic Organizations of Associated Labour (BOALS). A Community of Interest for Roads, or Siz za Ceste (SIZ), was made up of an assembly of delegates from entities having an interest in roads, such as trucking enterprises, factories, and urban and local road communities. Within Federal and Republic laws and guided by Social Contracts, the assemblies gave policy directives to their Secretariat which was charged with putting policy into practice. The Secretariat was headed by a Secretary who was an assembly appointee. With Design, Construction and Maintenance Divisions, the Secretariat of the SIZ resembled a public works department with the exception that little or no work was carried out by force account. For planning and design work, the SIZ employed Highway Institutes; for maintenance the specialized Road Maintenance Enterprises (RMEs) and for construction, independent contractors. 2.11 In 1990, the SIZs reorganized like most organizations in the former Yugoslavia to respond to the new Enterprise Law and other constitutional changes, and became Social Funds for Arterial and Regional Roads. The principal characteristic of these new Road Organizations (ROs) was that their administration was simplified. The RO, as it
 10 remains today, is governed by a managing board of 12 members rather than the much larger Assemblies which managed the SIZs. The Secretary is proposed by the managing board and confirmed by Parliament. 2.12 The RO manages the Arterial and Regional roads. The local roads are the responsibility of the municipal road authorities. The RO has a staff of 26 of which 14 are qualified professionals such as engineers, economists and a lawyer. They are responsible for preparing road development programs and financing plans as well as implementing policy directives given by Parliament. The law requires a feasibility study to be done on all investment proposals before their inclusion in the development program. These feasibility studies are usually done by the Highway Institute, an independent agency closely related to the University. The annual and mid-term development programs are approved by Parliament. E. Planning 2.13 The institutional framework and procedures laid down at the central level are adequate for formulating rational and efficient road development plans if the system is judiciously used. The existing system allows for orderly reconciliation of top-down strategies agreed at the Legislature with bottom-up programs representing the proposals of various communities. Based on these proposals, RO prepares Five-Year Plans and annual programs for road development for approval and ratification by Legislature. The administrative process, in principle, is conducive for formulating rational road development plans. However, actual functioning of the planning procedure is less than adequate. 2.14 Project Preparation and Selection. Investment programs approved by the Legislature include projects which have not been subjected to proper feasibility studies. At times, the selection of projects is based on considerations other than economic viability and efficiency. Even in those cases where feasibility studies have been carried out, the approach adopted is, at times, inadequate to yield sound results. There are also cases in which feasibility studies are used to justify a posteriori the investment decisions which have already been made. Nevertheless, resource constraints which are currently facing the country have made RO increasingly aware of the need for applying economic criteria in formulating their investment and expenditure programs. During the implementation of the proposed project, the Five-Year Highway Investment and Maintenance Plan (1996-2000) will be assessed to ensure that it is in line with the priority needs of the road network, projected transport demand, and projected revenues. The Bank has reviewed the 1995-1997 program and found it satisfactory (para. 2.21). During negotiations. it was agreed that RO shall not carry out investments for the expansion. upgrading and maintenance of its road network unless it has been established that such investments are economically viable and environmentally sound. on the basis of criteria and guidelines satisfactory to the Bank (para. 5.1 (a)). 2.15 RO has been contracting feasibility studies for major road investments to local firms. These studies have been prepared since 1974 in accordance with the Guidelines for Preparing Highway Feasibility Studies which were developed with Bank assistance. Individual feasibility studies have, since 1974, incorporated various improvements to the

Background 3.1 The East-West corridor links the port of Durres (Albania) with Skopje, Sofia, and the port of Burgas in Bulgaria. The need to upgrade the portion of the corridor located in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to accommodate growing domestic traffic was being addressed under the Bank's Third Highway Sector Project for Yugoslavia. The loan was approved by the Bank on June 20, 1990 but was cancelled prior to its effectiveness when the former Yugoslavia was dissolved. Nevertheless, because of the urgency of the investments, the RO went ahead with contracting works in three of the four appraised road sections and is financing them with its own budget. Priority sections of the Albanian part of the road corridor are being upgraded under the ongoing IDA Credit 2499-ALB, but much of the road to Durres will remain in poor condition until financing is available under a proposed new IDA credit to Albania in 1996. The proposed loan effectively reinstates the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's participation in the cancelled loan. The proposed project has been changed from what had been included in the Third Highway Sector Project to address the country's major transport need, which is to provide a link to the outside world through its neighbors, Albania and Bulgaria, in the East-West corridor.

ECONOMIC EVALUATION A. Benefits and Beneficiaries 4.1 The proposed project would improve the efficiency of the road transport sector by reducing overall transport costs. Quantifiable benefits will be in the form of vehicle operating cost (VOC) savings, i.e., lower fuel consumption, tire wear and general vehicle maintenance costs, and time and wage savings. Also, the present value of estimated future road expenditures will be reduced by avoiding more expensive interventions at a later date. 4.2 The benefits would accrue to a large and widespread number of beneficiaries. Lower road transport costs and time savings will benefit vehicle owners as well as users. Private users such as individual car owners, bus passengers and own account transporters will capture benefits directly. In the case of trucking and intercity bus services, the benefits accrue first to vehicle owners, but are expected to be passed to producers and consumers in the form of lower freight rates and fares, given the competitive nature of the road transport industry in the country. B. Cost and Benefits 4.3 Feasibility studies for the works in the Tetovo-Gostivar and Kichevo-Botun roads were prepared by a local consulting firm following methodologies developed in 1973 with Bank assistance under the previous loans to the former Republic of Yugoslavia and
 24 updated in 1994. All costs and benefits were evaluated in constant 1994 prices. Financial costs and prices have been converted to economic prices. Traffic growth rates for the Tetovo-Gostivar road have been estimated at 4.3% p.a. until 1996 and 1.1 % thereafter for private vehicles; about 1.1% p.a. for buses and 3.9% p.a. for freight vehicles. In the case of the Kichevo-Botun road, there were similar growth rate assumptions, except that bus traffic was also expected to grow at about 4% p.a. VOC's were calculated as a function of velocity and subsequently adjusted according to estimates made using the Bank's HDM model in countries with similar characteristics. 4.4 The economic rates of return (ERR) for the investments in the Tetovo-Gostivar and Kichevo-Botun roads are 18% and 23% respectively. The economic viability of the road works is not dependent on the continued interruption of North-South transit. The economic benefits of the Tetovo-Gostivar capacity expansion, was carried-out with a base traffic of 6900 vehicles per day, a level that was already attained in 1983, when the road served only domestic traffic. Traffic declined to about 4000 vehicles per day in 1992 and recuperated to an AADT of about 6900 in 1993. To a great extent, traffic growth in the last few years can be attributed to the rapid growth of motorization (para. 2.5), and to the opening up of communications with Albania and Bulgaria. Freight vehicles account for 14% of the total traffic, of which it would be highly unlikely that more than 50% would be diverted to North- South connections once the country's situation goes back to normal. In this scenario, the IRR for the Tetovo-Gostivar road works would drop to 14%. This is a very conservative estimate of the economic viability of the project, since a resumption of the economic activity to the levels of the early 80s would more than offset the impact of traffic diversion and increase the benefits of the project by about 50%. In the case of the Kichevo-Botun road, traffic diversion would reduce the ERR from 23% to 20%. Table 4.1 presents the costs and benefits of the road works. Feasibility studies for the road works will be entered in the project file. 4.5 Although the benefits from developing and implementing a Pavement Management System are difficult to quantify, the introduction to the RO of tools to optimize the allocation of resources throughout the life of the road, is expected to result in substantial savings in road maintenance. C. Overall Evaluation and Risks 4.6 The project does not present any technical or environmental risks. The main risk is related to the fragile political and economic situation, which may impact the availability of counterpart funds. That risk, however, is within acceptable levels because of the high priority of the road works, the historic financial independence and solvency of RO, the small share that the proposed investments represent in RO's budget (less than 10%), and the amount of retroactive financing proposed for the project. There are also risks related to the possible lack of coordination among the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania and Bulgaria, but the present framework of consultation and coordination under the auspices of the G-24 group and the EU, provides sufficient assurances on the commitment of these countries to improve border crossings.

doc.abstracts: The main objectives of the Transit Facilitation Project are to assist the Government to: 1) address the crisis created for transport in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia caused by the closure of the Serbian and Greek borders, through the facilitation of East-West transport so as to reduce transport costs; and 2) strengthen the road management capabilities of the Ministry of Transport and Communications, the Ministry of Urban Development (MTC), Civil Engineering, and Environment (MUDCEE), and the Republican Road Organization (RO) of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The project will have three components: 1) the civil works component will improve the country's access to the ports of Bulgaria and Albania through the rehabilitation and upgrading of about 60 km of the East-West Corridor; 2) the transit facilitation component will fund technical assistance and equipment for the development and implementation of a modern customs system and the improvement of transit times; and 3) the institutional strengthening component will fund technical assistance and training to strengthen MTC, MUDCEE and RO in the area of economic evaluation of different road interventions and life-cost planning for pavement management.
